boardgame.name: Switch It
boardgame.description:
A fun & challenging game with a messy room & chaos of night and day. Look out the window, is it sunny outside? Is your messy room full of lights and colors? If so, hurry up and find the COLOR that appears the most. But if it’s night then everything changes! The room is dark and full of shadows, no colors can be seen, only the shapes of the objects. This time try and spot the OBJECT that appearS the most. Hey! Pay attention! Two more objects might be hiding among your mess! a Flashlight and a curtain. They switch things around and turn day into night and night into day creating a FUN MESS OF A CHALLENGE!

How to play?
1The youngest player starts by flipping the first card of the deck and placing it next to it so that the objects side of the card is face up. Now there is the deck of cards with a window card on top and an objects card next to it. If the window card shows day then the players must try and spot the COLOR that appears the most on the card.
2If the window card shows night then the players must try and spot the object that appears the most on the card. Then another card is flipped from the pile by the next player and the game continues.

3
Beware! There are two special objects that change things around. When they appear it doesn’t matter whether its night or day in the window because they switch things around! The winner of the game is the player who collected the most cards.

boardgame.name: Shadow Games
boardgame.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Shadow Games, you must gather enough favours to secure the new star player for your guild. Players use various Plot and Agent cards to bribe, steal, and earn favour, but it is not enough to simply play the cards you receive. Fortune favours the bluffers! Play a card from your hand, and call it anything you want. If you convince your opponents of your lies, you will not only reap the rewards of the card you pretended to have but also gain a powerful bluff bonus that will accelerate your victory. Just don’t get caught— it will cost you valuable favours to save face.

Set in Guild Ball's devious, backstabbing Empire of the Free Cities, Shadow Games is a fast paced game for 2-6 cunning players.

Shadow Games will appeal to all Guild Ball players and any fans of compact, quick-paced card games that involve betraying your friends! Easy to learn and addictive, it's fun for all the family and fast—one game only takes about 15 minutes!

boardgame.name: Farce Card Game
boardgame.description:
Description from the publisher:

Farce is an innovative new word game with an inventive step which creates new possibilities for players to outwit each other and have fun.

The inventive step in Farce divides the English Language into 3 elements (3 types of card) so that multiple cards may be combined to create new and original witty sentences. This hasn’t been done before and is an original feature of Farce.

Farce cards contain fragments of comedy which have been designed to combine with other fragments to generate new and original witty sentences. For each round of Farce each player combines up to 12 cards (comprised of the 3 elements) to make a witty sentence which they then read out to the group. Players use their own creativity to produce something uniquely funny with their cards which they then share with the group. The player who gets the most laughs wins the round.

The group decides on each round which player received the most laughs and awards a Farce Point. If there is any dispute then the dealer for that round has the final say. The dealer rotates after each round.

Farce includes 22 Wild Cards which allow players to insert the name of a fellow player into their farcical sentence, and thereby direct their sentences at each other and make fun of each other. This makes the game all about the players.

Farce is aimed at players aged 17+ as the outputs of the game can include adult humour.

The number of possible card permutations playable is virtually infinite. Players can always create something new with Farce, something original and funny which no one has ever heard before.

boardgame.description:
Be sweet! Be cute! Try to please the humans and be the most cuddled cat! Roll your dice, see how the human is feeling, be mischievous, sweet, or silly! Fun for the whole family!

Each turn players roll their cat dice to determine if they take cuddle tokens from the pool of human cuddles, put cuddles back into the pool, are silly, steal cuddle tokens from other players, or roll the special human die. boardgame.name: Nightlancer
boardgame.description:
Nightlancer is a competitive cyberpunk game set in the unique dystopian future of 2099. Each player must guide their Nightlancer through a hazardous underworld career, intent on securing their future before society collapses around them.

Each player controls one of 10 unique Nightlancers. They take on challenging missions with multiple choice paths, choosing the option that best utilizes their abilities and options. If they are successful they get paid.

They can invest the money either to improve their pool of options with Black Market or Training cards, or they can invest the money in their Prospects to try to secure victory.

Players can use their hand of Contact cards to gain advantages or obstruct their opponents throughout each game round, or they can save them to help complete Agendas - giving them another path to Prospects.

The player with the most Prospects at the end of the game is the winner.

Nightlancer includes solitaire and cooperative optional rules.

boardgame.name: 5-Minute Dungeon
5분 던전
boardgame.description:
5-­Minute Dungeon is a chaotic, co-­operative, real-­time card game in which players have only five minutes to escape the randomized dungeon. Communication and teamwork are critical to survival because there's no time to form a carefully considered plan — and no predicting what dangers lie ahead.

In more detail, players assume the role of one of ten heroes, each with special cards and abilities. Once the five-minute timer starts, the race is on to defeat all the monsters inside the dungeon. In order to defeat a monster, players must match symbols from their hand with ones on the monster's card. At the end of each dungeon is a powerful dungeon boss — and after the first boss is defeated, the campaign continues to the second boss. Each boss, and each randomized dungeon, gets harder until players reach the fifth and final boss.

boardgame.name: Cassette Juego: Combate Espacial
boardgame.description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portable boardgames that were created in Spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other South American countries.(produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box. The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

Combate Espacial (Space Combat) was a spin and move game were players try to destroy the enemy spaceship as hunting the spaceship around the board. You spin to move and the first to get the enemy spaceship will be attack.

Lairs with vast treasure await heroes who have the endurance to travel through treacherous locations, are clever enough to overcome encounters with dangerous charlatans, and are brave enough to defeat the fearsome monsters that lurk within.

Win the most treasure and lead your heroes to victory!

boardgame.name: The World Council
boardgame.description:
The World Council is a secret committee unknown to most. They gather leaders from various countries in the globe to determine policy of our world. Its main objectives is maintaining peace, fostering social and economic development, and make sure the world is sustainable for mankind. However, result always comes with a price, the development for the general well-being can also foster the coming Doomsday. Can councilors work together for a better future?

The World Council is a strategic board game for 3 to 8 players. You are one of the country leaders in "The World Council". All players strive to be the first to achieve their countries’ objectives, which determined by their country cards, while preventing the ambition of other leaders, as well as, the end of the world. Player achieves his country’s objectives to win the game.

Each player begins the game with one of the following country cards (Super Power, Totalitarian State, Developed Country, Developing Country, Island Country) which give them different countries’ objectives and an uneven number of hands depends on which country you started with.

Doomsday Cards are used to Presents the closeness of 4 types of Doomsday (World War Index, Starvation index, Global Warming Index, Drought Index). Action Cards provide strategy for Councilors to gain advantage for their country. Building Cards need Resources to construct, but they can also provide Resources or even strategic superiority for their countries and construction of some buildings could also be a part of the objectives to win. Every card have a natural resources value showed on the upper left which can be used to pay building cost of other building. Using natural resources will cause the rise of Doomsday Index, but Resources provided by building will not.

Prepare for the tension and conflict coming from the other players, you will never know when will they be ally or your foe. Each game will be quick and simple, but always a different experience!

boardgame.name: CreaCity
boardgame.description:
INTRODUCTION TO THE GAME
A stormy period of the election to the City Council has just finished. The current model of managing cities has been hugely criticized. Many of the changes that took place in Poland and in the world resulted in the search for new ways of dealing with the problem.

The project CreaCity takes place in a number of big and small places scattered all over the world. Your city has become one of the participants of this great plan aimed at fixing the world.

The project assumes forming a Small Council for one term of office, which will deal with critical issues and those demanding immediate action. Your task will be to take decisions which satisfy the residents and indicate the direction of the development of the city, and at the same time avoid bringing it to bankruptcy.

This experiment may reveal new future leaders, so, even if you do not succeed, this game might be the beginning of something fantastic, both for you and the entire world.

CreaCity is a live action board game, during which players take on the role of councillors during the meetings of the Small City Council.

Each player will receive their character card stating their objectives and the committee they belong to. Each round of the game means very intense 45 minutes, during which committee members will be entrusted with Small and Big Challenges. It is these Challenges that CreaCity will be based on and, depending on the decisions taken by the players, the situation in the city will be changing.

The city is symbolized by a map divided into 8 regions. There are two dice placed in each region: a satisfaction dice (blue) and a dissatisfaction one (red).

Every time players take a binding decision, its effects will be transferred onto the board – satisfaction in the region will change (by changing the values on the dice), general satisfaction in the city and the available budget will change as well, and special buildings will appear.

Players start with a high degree of social trust and their decisions are aimed at gaining the largest general satisfaction possible. Af ter 5 rounds the game ends and the players check who accomplished the greatest number of objectives. Depending on the condition of the city, the entire Small Council receives appropriate number of victory points

GAME OBJECTIVES
For a period of 5 rounds you must not let the city go bankrupt. It happens when:

on the board, there will be 5 region bankruptcy tags.
The Dissatisfaction Tag will cross field number 30.


What is more, fight for your personal result and accomplish your objectives.

boardgame.name: Koth: Chronicles of War
boardgame.description:
Koth is a two-player, fantasy-themed duel card game in which players assume the roles of the two attendents (Sina or Ames) of the god of war; Koth of the game world, to decide the outcome of a battle between Orcs and Humans.

The game consists of a single deck of 52 cards. It is shared by both players to draw cards. There are 20 different kinds of units in the deck and these units are commanded onto the battlefield. Each unit has an ATTACK and a DEFENSE value. These values are used to dominate (attack) and hold (defend) a column. Some units also have ABILITIES (band, flank, rage, rally, and support) which give units additional skills than these two.

The battlefield is divided into five sections. Each section is called a "column" and players compete to dominate those columns. To dominate a column a unit's ATTACK must be at least equal to the unit's DEFENSE that is holding it.

Players have 10 Command Points (CP) for each round and they can command as many units as they please -provided they don't go over CP. Each unit has a CP cost equal to its ATTACK value.

Players start the game with three cards and draw one card at the start of their turns, and they take turns to command units onto the battlefield.

To win a game, one player must either control all of the five columns. In cases which this is not possible (i.e. when there's no more cards to draw and/or play) the player holding the most columns win the game. And whenever a player wins two consecutive games s/he wins the battle.

boardgame.name: Alien Flame
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

An Adventure Suitable for Characters with 6-10 Current Resources.

The galaxy is becoming less mysterious every day. Corporation scientists are unravelling the secrets of the worlds while the Palantor unlock incredible new technologies. It has become rare to encounter something that science simply cannot explain - yet the Twi-Far have. The Faren, strange beings of pure energy, make up one half of the Twi-Far pairing, but no one really knows where they came from or what they are doing here.

When the Twi-Far research vessel, “The Flame” unexpectedly veers off course and heads directly for pirate territory, the scientist Elidrav fears the worst. It will take a swift and cunning team to track down “The Flame” and bring it back before the pirates snatch it away. But what exactly were the scientists aboard “The Flame” researching, and why did it so suddenly change course?

Solving these mysteries will put the PCs face-to-face with deadly secrets, fierce pirates, and innumerable twists and turns. Will the PCs prevail, or will their actions put the entire Twi-Far race at risk?

boardgame.name: The Knight's House
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Knight's House is a five storey Tower protected by a small wall. It's the perfect location for a base of operations, or somewhere to rest between adventures.

The Knight's House is a set of printable dungeon floorplans compatible with any RPG/Dungeon-Crawl game. It can be used as a standalone gameboard, or combined with any same-scale tileset.

The Knight's House is a multiple level set, comprising 5 battlemaps (each depicting a different floor)

Ground Floor (20x20) - The ground floor of the tower is surrounded by a small courtyard with stables and a jousting list, with a strong wall. The ground floor houses a large kitchen and store.
First Floor (12x10) - This floor holds the Great Hall, where the Knight greets visitors.
Second Floor (12x10) - An armoury and combat training arena.
Third Floor (12x10) - The knight's solar, with bed, garderobe, dining area, small study and chapel
Fourth Floor (12x10) - An attic bedroom for squires and men-at-arms.


The Knight's House is part of the Tower Builder range. You can put the floors in any order, or add in floors from other maps in the Tower Builder range to make custom towers.
Each Tower is associated with a different class or character type, making them perfect as a base for your character.

boardgame.name: OutLawed!
動物通緝令
boardgame.description:
Overwhelmed by the stress of the hooligan hootenanny that's overrunning the bustling town of Bandit Bluff, the resident deputy has up and left his post! Sheriff Croc Holliday is shuffling and hustling to find his next deputy. Looking to fill the vacancy, Croc has decided to put a pool of new recruits to work helping clean up some of Bandit Bluff's most wanted outlaws and will choose the most dedicated to be the new deputy! A little lying, some stealthy scheming, and the sense to know a good time to tell the truth might just help give a leg up over the rest of the herd. Who will out-law the other applicants to become the new deputy?

OutLawed! is a social game of bluffing, truth-telling, and out-thinking your opponents. Each player has an identical set of eleven outlaw cards imagined as animals escaped from the zoo somewhere in the wild, wild west. Over a series of rounds, players take turns playing a card face down and making a claim about which character card they played. Players are free to tell the truth about the character played or to make a bold-faced lie! After players have played cards and made their claims, all the characters are revealed and each player assesses whether or not they have met their outlaw's "apprehend if" condition. Players who were successful add their outlaws to their jail pile while all other players place the card back in their hand. Lionel Manesworth, for example, can be captured only if you tell the truth. The Vixen Twins get nabbed when others are convinced to play the same card during the round. Lawman Croc Holliday will catch anybody who isn't on the up and up.

Once a player fills up their jail, everyone compares their total reward value of apprehended cards to see who has earned the most rewards and gets to fill the vacant position as deputy of Bandit Bluff.

boardgame.name: Brain Flip
boardgame.description:
Give the wrong answer on purpose! In Brain Flip, one player picks a card and the other players try to guess which card it is by asking questions. The twist: every answer given will be the opposite of the truth. Train your brain to do mind bending gymnastics and you will be the winner!

Display a number of cards on the table. Mentally pick one and prepare to answer the players’ questions. The players will try to guess the card you picked by asking questions that have to be answer only by YES or NO. You must always answer the opposite. It looks simple, but it will trick their brains. Don’t get confused! Play smart and find the hidden card! Tally the points to see who is the winner!

In the end, whoever collects the most carrot chips wins!

boardgame.name: KoonKan
boardgame.description:
This card game is played with a 61-card deck. The deck has four suits (Star, Flag, Cross and Seal) each with cards numbered 1-15, along with a Koon card bearing the picture of a raccoon.

Players are dealt 10 cards each to start. On each turn, a player draws a card from the top of the remaining deck or of the discard pile, plays a set or more if he wishes, and discards a card. As in rummy, sets can be three or more of a kind or three or more of a suit in sequence.

However, in addition to laying down sets of their own, players may add cards to any set or sequence of any player on the board. The Koon card is wild and may be used in any set, but if it is played on the end of a sequence, the player holding that actual card may play it, and add the Koon to the other end of the sequence.

The object is to be the first player to empty his hand. The last card in a hand may be discarded or may be used in a set, with no discard. Other players add up the value of cards remaining in their hand and score that many points. Game winner is the one with the fewest points at the end of the agreed number of hands.

boardgame.name: Jeu du Juif-Errant
boardgame.description:
This mid-19th Century game is laid out like Game of Goose, with an inward spiral of 63 spaces, but it is based on the 1844 novel Le Juif-Errant (The Wandering Jew), by Eugene Sue. The starting (lower-left) corner of the board has an impage of Sue at work writing the novel. The other corners and each space on the track show a character or incident from the 1400-page book. The center of the board shows the Wandering Jew arriving in Paris, and also includes the rules.

As in Game of Goose, players make an initial ante, and may be forced to pay more into the pot as a result of landing on certain squares. The first player to reach the end of the track takes the pot.

boardgame.description:
Why would someone attack a policeman? It's one of many questions you've been obsessing about since you received this ransom demand following your daughter's kidnapping.

As you begin walking toward the front door of a manor house deep in the woods in Captive, your hand cramping above your weapon, your spirit satiated with fear, you anticipate that things will turn out badly. Your intuition will not betray you — even if you were far from imagining what was actually in reserve for you on the most horrifying evening of your entire existence.

Captive is a comic combined with a game, one title in a series subtitled "The comic in which you are the hero". You embody a character in a immersive story in which your choices guide your progress. You have a character sheet akin to those used in role-playing games that tracks your possessions, your special abilities, your coins, and your victory points. In general, gameplay consists in following the comic's panels — which contain clues, riddles and traps — and making choices about where to go and what to do, while using your visual perception to collect clues and be smart enough to resolve the riddles. As in any game, you can lose — sometimes really badly!

boardgame.name: Magitics
boardgame.description:
An unusual structure has emerged on the mountainside that one would think to be desolate: a long-lost temple fort of Artheastam, the Kingdom of Light — or is it rather a slaughterhouse? Several adventurers have been brave enough to attempt to discover the secret of the temple, yet none returned to tell the tale. What could this secret be? Why do so many go about risking their lives? Are they aware of what lies ahead of them?

The Kingdom of Artheastam has come to the decision to send its three most excellent warriors to face the peril. This will surely not be watched from the sideline by either the offsprings of darkness or the Mountaindeep or by the dispersed spacebenders. The future of their world is at stake, and they want to get hold of their legacy.

In Magitics, a team of heroes controlled by a player must confront the other players' heroes in a diverse arena. Their aim is to be the winner of this fight and get a piece of a crystal that involves magical powers, hidden by Sethemet, the space-time magician.

In this conflict, all players control separate hero troops. During these battles, they may get spells, magic items and valuable loot, which strengthen them. They may receive different benefits, too. Players choose heroes that they want to activate; these heroes can perform various actions up to their available action points. The players' goal is to ensure that with the right tactical decisions their resourceful heroes prove to be stronger than others or completely overcome their opponents by the end of the round. If all players activated their heroes, a new round begins.

boardgame.name: Sushi Go!
boardgame.description:
Sushi Go! is a digital adaptation of the popular card game of the same name. Players compete for the highest score, by picking sushi from a conveyor belt, and scoring the sushi they took at the end of each round. Each type of sushi earns points in different ways, and players must max their combos and prevent opponents from doing the same.

Play a pair of Tempuras for 5 points, but play one on its own and you'll get none! Nigiris can be dipped in Wasabi to triple their points! Pudding doesn't score until the end of the game, but it can clinch a victory or cause a defeat!

Sushi Go is simple enough to play with the family, but thousands of sushi combinations will keep even diehard strategy fans playing. Do you take a Tempura to get points for a pair? Or take Sashimi to stop your opponent from completing his triplet? Pudding doesn't earn points in the round, but you'll lose points at the end of the game if you have the fewest!

Sushi Go (the card game) was created by Phil Walker-Harding, and published by Gamewright.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.description:
Subatomic: An Atom Building Game is a deck-building game in which players compete to build a number of available elements, which score them points.

Each player starts with the same small deck of cards that consist of proton, neutron, and electron cards. They use these cards to build upon their current atom (by playing these cards face-up as subatomic particles) in an attempt to construct one of the available element cards. Alternatively, players may use their hand of cards to purchase more powerful cards for later use (by playing them in combinations of face-down cards as energy and face-up cards as subatomic particles). Subatomic introduces a unique variation on deck-building with a highly accurate chemistry theme, with the ultimate goal of building elements to score points, but allowing many varying types of strategies.

boardgame.name: L'isola dei famosi
boardgame.description:
A board game based on the reality show "L'isola dei famosi" (Survivor in English).
There are 12 castaways, independently of the number of players. Each player receives secretly a card with 6 castaways they have to keep on the island.
Each round players challenge to be the group leader. There are different kinds of challenge: dexterity, acting, memory, trivia, words, calculation, deduction.
The winner receives food, chooses which castaway will be immune and votes the castaway he wants to eliminate. Then, the other players vote the castaway they want to eliminate.
There is a runoff voting between the 2 selected castaways: after it one castaway is eliminated.
After the last round the castaways are ranked according to their position (from 1 to 12) and players score points accordingly.
The player with the most point is the winner.

boardgame.name: Il nuovo gioco dell'oca + La lepre e la tartaruga
boardgame.description:
A box with 2 games:
1) Il nuovo gioco dell'oca
A mix between The game of goose and Ludo. Each player tries to move his 3 geese to the end of path (2 adult and 1 child): during his turn he rolls the die and moves one goose. According to the square he lands, he can move forward, backward, roll again or move back an opponent goose to closer lake. If 2 or 3 geese of the same player are on the same square, they are safe. An adult can "eat" an opponent child, a child can't "eat" an opponent adult.

2) La lepre e la tartaruga
A racing game for 2 players, based on the Aesop's tail "The hare and the tortoise".
Each player rolls the die and moves his figure, then he can put a tile on the path and/or move again if he lands to a tile or a square with a number. Each tile has a number between 1 and 3, with + or -: so a player will move forward or backward 1-3 squares.
The game ends after one player completes 2 rounds.

In Hounded, players will either be the cunning fox, trying to elude capture, or the determined hunter, trying to hunt down the fox.

In the game. each player moves their pawns and turns over tiles as they do, sometimes triggering effects and sometimes not. While the fox character is alone, the hunter has a team of hounds to help him hunt the fox. All the hunter has to do to win is either corner the fox with his dogs or force the fox to end his turn next to the hunter himself. For the fox to win, it has to run out the clock, which is done by either finding the three timepiece tiles or flipping over 43 of the 49 tiles. Once time runs out, the hunter has to retire for the day and the fox escapes!

boardgame.name: SupraRAM 2000
boardgame.description:
User Summary
Memory expansion for the desktop Amigas (Amiga 2000, Amiga 3000, Amiga 4000) fitting the ZorroII slots.

The card was preinstalled with 2 MB RAM but could be expanded to 4 MB, 6 MB or 8 MB by adding more groups of 16 1Mx1 (511000) DIPs (70-120ns).
A fully loaded board of 8 MB would require a total og 64 DIPs.

Board was fitted with a jumper for enable/disable.

Manual
Adding RAM to the SupraRAM 2000 Board (Optional)
The SupraRAM 2000 can be purchased with 2, 4, 6, or 8MB of RAM
already installed. If your SupraRAM 2000 contains 2, 4, or 6MB of
RAM, you can add more RAM (in 2MB blocks), when it's convenient
for your needs or budget

boardgame.name: Keep Your Friends Close
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The PCs are part of a diplomatic crew in the service of Pappa Doc’s railways. A particularly crucial train is coming through the mountain bottleneck of Tiger Valley to dock with an oil refinery. The whole railway is desperately short on oil, due to mounting attacks from NORAD-affiliated groups, and this train only has enough diesel to get through this route — having to go back would mean adding on an extra five hundred kilometres to their journey.

But something's not quite right in Tiger Valley. Though they're friendly enough, a tension lies just beneath the surface. Is this just due to recent bandit attacks, or is some other game afoot? The PCs will need to keep their wits about them, and their ears to the ground if they hope to get out of the valley in one piece - or at all.

A one-shot scenario for Infected Zombie RPG, for 1-6 players, and estimated to take 4-6 hours.

boardgame.name: 100 Items to Find in an Occultist's Chambers
boardgame.description:
This is a list of 100 different occult-related that players might find in rooms belonging to an occultist. The items are suitable for most settings where such may be encountered.

The items cover various different types. There is a distinct edge towards modern paganism and Wicca practices, as these most commonly use items, but there are some from other traditions too. These are all genuine types of occult and pagan items. Whether or not the items listed have any in-game value other than decorative is up to the GameMaster.

Each entry has the item, and may have additional details on them too, which can result in many more items than the 100 listed. They can be used as decorative items should the players be rummaging through the possessions of a suitable NPC.

Some examples are:

9. Bags (Drawstring bags, different materials, velvet, leather, cotton, silk, satin or plastic)
10. Bath Supplies (Ritual bathing and cleansing salts, oils, soaps and lotions)
11. Bell (Small, hand held)

- Publisher's description

boardgame.name: 100 Things to Find in a Survivalist's Retreat
boardgame.description:
This is a list of 100 items that may be found in a survivalist's retreat, whether this be an extensive construction out in the wilds or a simple bunker or room in an urban setting. Although there are 100 items on the list, many of these can then be split into further items.

Survivalists don't just have guns; they also have other things needed to survive, such as food, supplies, hunting equipment, tools and power sources. These can be useful for any players in any post-apocalyptic setting, whether this be a zombie apocalypse or a traditional nuclear war. they aren't solely of use in those settings either, as they could also be used if the players are investigating or infiltrating a survivalist or survivalist organisation before the end of the world.

61. Maps (Of the local area, including navigation equipment such as compasses)
62. Matches (Strike anywhere, kept dry)
63. Meat Grinder (For mincing raw meat)

boardgame.description:
The Fleet Commander Resource is a participation prize given to players who participated in Month 1, "Attack on Gowron," of the Star Trek: Attack Wing Storyline Organized Play Event, Klingon Civil War.

When using the Fleet Commander resource, you may assign two captains to a single ship. That ship may use both captains' abilities as normal throughout the game. The Captain Skill Number for the ship is equal to the higher skill of the two Captains, plus 1.

Additionally, at the start of the game that ship may add 1 to either it's Shield or Hull value (but only to a maximum of 6 for Hull value).

The Fleet Commander is considered a resource and costs 5 SP.

boardgame.description:
The Auxiliary Power Resource is a participation prize given to players who participated in Month 2, "Battle of Mempa," of the Star Trek: Attack Wing Storyline Organized Play Event, Klingon Civil War.

When using this resource, at the start of the game, you place 5 Auxiliary Power Tokens on the resource's card. During the game, one per round, a single ship in your fleet can move one of the Auxiliary Power Tokens from the resource to the ship to gain one of several benefits:

1) Roll 1 extra attack or defense die

2) Place 1 evade token beside the ship

3) Repair 1 Shield

The resource is discarded once all 5 tokens are remove. The resource costs 5 SP.

Simon Cassidy struggled for years to develop technology that would allow him to travel through time. boardgame.name: Treasure Hoards #1
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Your PCs are deep in the dungeon and have just defeated a terrifying dragon! As they bandage their wounds, and ready their fallen friend’s bodies for return to the surface, they look around and ask “So what treasure’s in the dragon’s hoard, anyway?” At that point, unless the GM has prepared a detailed list of treasure, the PCs get (possibly) literally tons of coins and some generic magic items. (After all, most GMs have better things to do with their prep time than generate descriptions for stuff the PCs will likely sell).

Treasures & Trinkets: Treasure Hoards #1 banishes these problems by providing a veritable hoard of 25 pre-generated, richly detailed treasure hoards for challenges 0-4 ready to insert into almost any GM’s campaign.

boardgame.name: Coldwater (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Widely thought of as a haven for smugglers and other miscreants, rumours swirl as thickly about Coldwater as the persistent sea fogs that sometimes blanket the place for days at a time. Set at the head of a muddy cliff top path, Coldwater is an isolated, dismal place. Its folk are sullen, ugly people and even the village’s ruler hates the place. For all that, Coldwater can be a place of opportunity and adventure. Sometimes, pirates drop anchor off the coast to deal with the local smugglers while rumours of a sunken stair and a nearby cove of ill aspect bring a steady stream of adventurers to the village.

boardgame.name: Wellswood (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A busy, prosperous village, Wellswood is justly famed for the warm welcome travellers find in the village’s taverns and inns and for its most striking feature: Lake Thraren—a subterranean lake lying deep below the village’s foundations. The villagers catch the exotic fish swarming in its deep, cold waters and on its shore stand the fortress home of the dwarf clan of Erdikr. Here long before humans colonised the land above, these secretive dwarves serve Lord Issakainen, maintaining the village’s many wells, but let none enter their lightless home. All is not peaceful in Wellswood, however. Merchants and villagers alike grumble at the slowly increasing burden of taxes levied by the greedy Lord Issakainen while others have begun to wonder exactly what clan Erdikr are up to deep below the earth.

boardgame.name: Ashford (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Once a prosperous village, Ashford now stands as a decayed shadow of its former self. A year ago, it was a busy place; its streets and gardens echoing with the sounds of life, love and commerce. Then the stranger came and death followed upon his heels. Plague had come to Ashford. In his wake, he left the hacking coughs and pain-filled moans of the dying and the wails of the survivors mourning their dead. Over half the population died, and many of the survivors packed and fled.

A few folk yet dwell in Ashford among the abandoned, deserted homes of their friends and neighbours but it is now a quiet, mournful place. Weeds choke its abandoned gardens and untilled fields. Wolves, foxes and other less natural predators gnaw at the weathered bones filling the village’s open plague pit. The surviving villagers are distrustful of strangers, shunning them whenever possible, and few find welcome, cheer or solace in Ashford.Village Backdrops are short, richly detailed supplements that each present a single village ready to insert into almost any home campaign. Perfect for use as a waystop on the road to adventure, as an adventure site themselves or as a PC’s home, Village Backdrop present the details so the busy GM can focus on crafting exciting, compelling adventures.

boardgame.name: Longbridge (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A hotbed of intrigue and deception, Longbridge is claimed by not one but two noble lords. Sprawled across both banks of a wide, swiftly flowing river forming the boundary between the rivals’ lands, the village grew up at either end of a fortified stone bridge of ancient dwarven artifice. A no man’s land of sorts, the bridge itself is huge; scores of travellers cross it every day and several businesses have established themselves upon its span to service their needs. Informally led by Einhard Kochel these free traders do not pay tax or offer fealty to either lord and fiercely resist both nobles’ overtures.
Longbridge is in turmoil. Rumourmongers whisper that bloody war will soon swirl across the span as one noble or the other seeks to settle the matter of its ownership once and for all. Others whisper of hidden stairs in the bridge’s pilings plunging deep below the riverbed to hidden, noisome catacombs of great antiquity and of the foul, ageless creatures lurking within.

boardgame.name: White Moon Cove (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

White Moon Cove is a respectable fishing town located in a cove which acts as an excellent, natural harbour. The inhabitants of this tightly-knit community are sober, hardworking and amiable fishermen, traders and other sturdy folk making their living from the sea.

Despite being a fairly peaceful and law-abiding place, White Moon Cove still hold many opportunities for adventure, from rumours of secret smuggler activity to an ancient and possibly haunted lighthouse. Yet, perhaps the most famous reason for White Moon Cove's notoriety is the mysterious underwater edifice known as the Sunken Pyramid which lies hidden far beneath the waves a few miles out to sea. The handful of sages and scholars possessing any knowledge of this massive stone structure debate whether it is a completely natural rock formation, a natural site that has somehow been intentionally modified, or something built long ago by human, or inhuman, hands.

boardgame.name: Ogoola Karuta: 1-100 English Complete
boardgame.description:
Ogoola Karuta is a westernized version of a 400-year-old Japanese card game called Hyakunin-isshu Karuta. The game is sometimes described as intellectual martial arts. It is about listening and being extremely focused and fast, just like the Samurai with their swords. Only here you fight with cards instead.

The game is comprised of two decks of cards, the Reader deck and the Player deck. Cards in the Reader deck contain short poems or poetry quotations while cards in the Player deck contain only the second part of these poems. To begin the game, a Reader is chosen (or you may opt to use the Reader app) and the players are divided into two teams sitting/standing on opposite sides of the table or play area. The Reader shuffles the Reader deck and the Players mix, split evenly the Player deck between the teams and place them face-up in 3-4 rows in front of them. The Reader will read the complete poetry quotation on the reading cards and the player that finds the matching playing card first takes that card and puts it aside. If the card taken was on your opponent's side, you must give one card from your side to your opponent. The first team that has no cards left on their side is the winner (you must get rid of all your cards first, to win).

The game is set in Japan during the Genpei war (1180-1185). In order to win the war, you need a strategy. Place the cards you are familiar with close to you (in the beginning it is normal that none of the cards are familiar). If you know what cards your opponent is familiar with, place those cards as far as possible from them inside the playing field. Since the reader or app will always read the complete quotation, you do not need prior knowledge of the poems. Strategically place the playing cards in a way that you can find and take them quickly such as laying them alphabetically or categorize them under the same first words.

Ogoola Karuta Poetry Game is not a translation of the original Japanese game. In this edition, we have selected 100 quotes, new and old from well known poems written in the English language. It is the first western version of Hyakunin-isshu Karuta, which means Karuta: 100 poems by 100 poets.

boardgame.name: ARK - Scorched Earth
ARK: Scorched Earth
ARK: Survival Evolved – Scorched Earth
boardgame.description:
Stranded naked, dehydrated and starving on a fiery, drought-ridden desert world, players must immediately seek water, hunt for food, harvest new flora, craft new items, and build shelter from the extreme heat. Players who survive the harsh arid conditions can travel back and forth from the Scorched Earth map to the ARK: Survival Evolved main game, taking with them newly collected tools, weapons, and their new tamed creatures to impress their friends and dazzle their combatants.

Scorched Earth

Scorched Earth adds 12 new creatures with 5 variations, 60 new engrams, a new boss, and a whole new map. Being entirely a desert rather than an island surrounded by water, water collection becomes a more challenging obstacle. Natural water sources are rare, requiring the collection of water from other sources, such as cactus, water wells, Jugbugs, or Morellatops. Heat stroke is a potential side effect of too much heat exposure, having a similar effect to being drunk. Also the naturally harsh environment damages generators and certain structures.

Unique Features:


Super Heat, Sandstorms, and Electrical Storms.
Extremely hot temperatures in the day.
Evaporation of Water in Canteens and Water Jars.
Electrical Generators that take damage whenever used.
Heat Stroke, which causes damage and creates a blurry effect on-screen. (Similar to being drunk)
Oil and Water Veins, which can be used to produce Oil and Water, respectively.
Unique Creature: Phoenix




































StoryThe story is primarily told through notebooks and journals hidden all over the island, and through cutscenes that play after defeating all the bosses on each map. The Explorer Notes are either a Dossier or a piece of narrative from actual survivors.

Helena and Rockwell meet the dragon riding priestess from Ancient Egypt - Wali al Aswad, and learn that each artificial environment (a space station) orbiting earth acts as experimental group with genetically engineered wildlife to keep humans and other creatures contained within the artificial "ARK" islands. Anyone that becomes too advanced or discovers too much about the true nature of the ARKs, is destroyed by the floating obelisks. Wali al Aswad is one of the few natives of Scorched Earth aware of the ARKs true nature, having seen first hand how they destroy whole groups of people. Most other residents of the desert however, such as those at Prophet's Rest, remain ignorant and worship the obelisks as gods. Aswad assists Helena and Rockwell in reaching another gateway but chooses to remain on Scorched Earth.

Events continue in the Aberration DLC.

boardgame.name: No Regerts: The Game of Art and Poor Life Choices
boardgame.description:
No Regerts: The Game of Art and Poor Life Choices is a light hearted, fast paced, pvp style card game that plays 2-6 players. Your objective is to be the most badass by the end of the game while making your friends look lame.

Now how? With the playing deck, each player has a "formation card" to show you how your "body" is formed. Your body is made up of six tattooable limbs (two arms, two legs, a chest, and a back); and each limb holds enough space for 3 designs each (so 18 designs in total).

To fill these limbs, you have to get tattooed. The game consists of three types of cards: Positive Tattoos (indicated by their blue title color and positive value), Negative Tattoos (indicated by their red title color and negative value, and Modifier Cards (which have no number value and have only a gold bar at the bottom of the card).

Now game play is easy to learn. Each players starts with a hand size of 5 cards... which will remain for the game unless you have a card that says other wise. And you have four main actions on your turn.

1. Get tattooed:
This can be a positive or a negative tattoo. To get a positive tattoo, you have to discard either another positive tattoo or a modifier (which is good as gold even though it doesn't have a number value) since good tattoo artists don't work for free. To get a negative tattoo, you probably know someone working out of a van or basement that will give you tetanus along with a free tattoo, so negative tattoos are free and don't require a discard payment. Some cards, both positive and negative, have extra effects that are in their description bars under their titles.


Note if you can't or choose not to do either, you can discard two cards to pass. But to get to your second action, you have to get a tattoo on yourself first.


2. Open play:
This is where you can do as much as your hand allows. If you can pay for a second tattoo, you can get one. This is also where the use of modifiers come into play and where the pvp aspect comes in. There is a dreaded modifier known as "Bad Advice". This modifier is what mainly allows a player to play negative tattoos on other players. And there are other great modifiers that also will effect tattoos that are already in play.

3. Is a require discard.
This allows for a more balance deck as well as forces more strategy and less hording. There are cards that will effect the discard.

4. Is basically refresh. Fill your hand back to five (unless you have a card that says other wise).

The end game is determined when one player has filled their body, that player receives 5 bonus points, and everyone then totals their tattoo values to determine the winner. So just because you finished first, it doesn't mean you've won.

boardgame.name: Perlentauchen
boardgame.description:
Small, sparkling treasures are lying on the ground floor: colourful pearls hiding in shells. In Perlen Tauchen you play as pearl divers searching for these precious objects from the depth. You are salvaging and cracking the shells – but other divers are also on the scent of you and those pearls. To cap it all off you are struggling with the rough sea during your quest. The nacreous pearls reach their full value only when they join as chains, corresponding with your mission.
Your goal is to be the first to build the highly coveted pearl chains. The winner will be the pearl diver achieving that goal most frequent.

The shell cards lay down with their back side, like they were laying on the sea floor. There are mission cards for 2, 3 or 4 players, showing the required shell colors for each of the ten rounds. Each player has two action cards on his hand. In every turn a player draws a third card and plays one of them. He may either turn one card of his own or on the sea floor, or take it to his own shell chain in front of him or do both, take and turn it. There are also action cards to steal from another player or swap with another players card. In the case of a "flush away" or a "seaquake" the player must play this card immediately. In the first case he has to lay one of his cards back on the sea floor, in the second case all cards from the sea floor will be drawn to their back sides and shuffled again.
A round ends when a player has fulfilled his mission for the current round. Afterwards all cards wil be shuffled again for the next round. All players now should achieve the goal of the following round. The players may play up to 10 rounds. Who wins the most rounds is winner of the game.

boardgame.name: Quodd Heroes
boardgame.description:
Quodd Heroes is a fast-paced modular, scenario-based adventure board game that plays like a combination of Super Smash Bros., Mario Kart and Legend of Zelda all wrapped into one. Whether it’s a simple point-to-point rally-style race, capture the flag or a quest to uncover hidden secrets each game is filled with unexpected events, lots of player interaction, ever-changing boards and a dash of mayhem.

The core mechanism in Quodd Heroes is something you’ve never seen before. Each player controls a different cube-shaped character miniature and player board. You then assign a different movement skill to five of the six sides of your character (the sixth side has an ability unique to your character). When you begin the movement phase on your turn you “tumble” your character into an adjacent space and perform the movement skill associated with the face-up side of your character. Skills include: Tumble, Jump, Slide, Diagonal Slide, and Dash.

While you work to complete the scenario’s objective(s), either on your own, cooperatively, or against other players, game boards which are laid out in grids present obstacles like walls, raging rivers, chasms, moving platforms, rotating board sections, trap doors, tunnels, teleporters and more. As you navigate the world you create new obstacles and shortcuts while battling your opponents by pushing them into pits, blocking their paths and fouling their plans.

As you explore the world you will find food, runes, items and pets in the form of cards. These cards enhance your abilities, slow your opponents and modify the world around you. If you use your movement skills and cards strategically you'll emerge as the greatest of the Quodd Heroes.

Player Turn Structure:

1. Play cards (power up): Play as many cards as you like from your hand. Power up and alter the board prior to movement.

2. Movement Phase: Perform your natural tumble by turning your hero miniature over into an adjacent space, activate any board elements on that space, then activate the movement skill associated with the side of your character that is now facing up. Move up to your maximum distance with that skill in any direction you like.

3. Play card (recover phase): You many play any additional cards you like during this phase.

4. Exploration phase: draw cards from the lineup of cards or the top of the deck equal to your exploration value

At the end of each round an upkeep phase includes:

- moving board elements and animals
- play a world event card that effects all players
- Adjust round tracker (in timed scenarios)
- all heroes upgrade their hero by selecting an upgrade tile and placing it in their upgrade track.
- First player mark passes to the left

boardgame.name: UnderQuest
boardgame.description:
In Under Quest you are in charge of a handful of characters in a small growing hamlet in between a larger town, and a notorious ruins. You goal is to build up your community by constructing buildings and your heroes by purchasing items in the market. There is also always the itch to go questing in the nearby ruins in an attempt to circumvent the traditional route to victory. The ruins are perilous and are all about risk vs reward.

All the mechanics work together to create a rich experience where each player feels the freedom to play on their own terms and are equally punished and rewarded for pressing their luck in the ruins.

On your turn, you may spend a character card(s) to take one of the following actions:

1) Questing - Send one or more characters into the nearby dungeon in search of rare items and treasures. This uses a press-your-luck mechanic in which you reveal one card at a time and if the total of all the ruin card's value ever exceeds that of the combined power of all the characters, you bust. You may cash out at any time before this and combine the treasures indicated on each ruin card. You also can gain immediate victory points by revealing a set number of cards.

2) Hire a new character - Send a character to the local inn to recruit a new character by paying a cost in gold. New characters tend to be more useful and skilled than the starting characters.

3) Contruct a Building - Send a character to purchase plans for a building that will be added to your hamlet. These building provide passive abilities and end game victory points.

4) Bribe the Merchants - You may spend a character to place any number of items into the merchant's pouch. Doing so increases the value of those items, so will will want to balance the amount to bribe with the amount you keep for yourself. The value of items will be revealed at game's end and will make up a portion of total victory points.

5) Entertain at the Inn - Send a character to entertain at the inn. The player reveals the top treasure card. If the card indicates a reward of gold, the player claims the shown amount as a tip from the audience. If the card is an item, they receive no tip.

6)Purchase from the Alchemist - Send a character to make a purchase from the Alchemist. You may purchase multiple items here. Most are potions, but all are one-use items that the player may use later during the game.

After a determined number of rounds the game ends and the player with the most victory points wins. The player with the most gold is the tiebreaker.

boardgame.name: Reformanda
boardgame.description:
Reformanda is a collaborative, educational and fun card game for 2-6 players. The players, as pirates, will hone their discernment skills and strategically collaborate, countering heresy with Scripture, using their abilities, weapons, loot and spiritual gifts to rescue those who have been infected with heresies. Let no man deceive you.

The Players win if at the end of the last Round at least 1 Pirate and 1 Church are standing. Each round has 3 Phases: Heresy, Dogma and Reckoning Phases. During the heresy phase, churches lean heretical(you flip over cards with symbols on the bottom and must play cards with matching symbols to discard the flipped over cards); during the dogma phase, the pirates battle the heresies(you play cards and draw back up); during the reckoning phases, any church or pirate containing three heresies becomes heretical. There are 12 rounds in total.

boardgame.name: TAILITS
boardgame.description:
TAILITS is an abstract strategy game for 2 players, Black and White, based on the Japanese logic puzzle LITS, and inspired by the game TAIJI. It is a follow-up to Battle of LITS by the same designer. Starting with Black, players take turns placing L-, I-, T-, and S-shaped tetrominoes from a shared supply onto the board. There are three restrictions:

1. Every new piece must share an edge with at least one of the pieces already on the board.
2. No two congruent pieces may share an edge.
3. No four cells in a 2x2 arrangement may all be covered by pieces.

Each piece has two black squares and two white squares. Players attempt to make large groups of squares of their color (horizontal, vertical, and diagonal connections count). When no more pieces can be played, whoever has the largest such group wins. In the event of a tie score, the player who made the last move wins.

boardgame.name: Sorcerer Summoning
boardgame.description:
From the Publisher's blurb:

Flux elementals, lightning drakes, scornful undead, and diabolical burnination!

In Sorcerer Summoning, Rob Heinsoo introduces all-new spells that connect with the sorcerer’s heritage talents. Summon powerful elementals, or an undead courtier of the Lich King who unleashes both damage and withering snobbery on your enemies.

Wield the sorcerous heritage of the Three to call forth an electric stream of lightning drakes!
Summon the Diabolist’s burnout elemental, and learn the true power of spell frenzy!
Tap the arcane magic of the Archmage and unleash bizarre flux elementals to demolish your foes!
Call up the Lich King’s undead toadies, who will demonstrate in word and deed why their master is the true ruler of the Dragon Empire!

All this, plus a detailed update of the overall summoning mechanics in 13th Age.

boardgame.name: Coin Tricks
boardgame.description:
From the Publisher's blurb:

How can we make those monster-guarded piles of coins more interesting…?

There are few things a sword-and-spell-slinging adventurer loves more than a full coin purse — so why not take advantage of it? Coin Tricks by Rob Heinsoo and Lynne Hardy turns the one thing that all PCs will literally die to obtain into a rich source of plot hooks and monsters. It includes:

Coin zombies, who make up for their slowness by using adventurers’ greed to ensnare them.
Coins found in living dungeons that appear to be from alternate versions of the Empire.
Ghoul-stamped coins, the mutilated currency of the undead.
Rules for Tower Thump, the dwarves’ favorite coin-based drinking game.
Normal-seeming gold coins that are also bat-winged demons devoted to chaos and destruction.
